question: Splinting of cervical root fracture is done for
prompt:
Splinting of cervical root fracture is done forA)40 days
B)4 months
C)4 weeks
D)14 days
output0: Splinting of cervical root fracture is typically done for 40 days to allow the fracture to heal properly. This is a common treatment approach for this type of injury.
output1: The splinting of cervical root fracture is typically done for a period of 4 months. This allows the fracture to heal properly and reduces the risk of complications such as nerve damage or deformity.
output2: The splinting of cervical root fracture is typically done for 4 weeks to allow the bone to heal and prevent further injury.
output3: The splinting of cervical root fracture is typically done for 14 days. This allows for the fracture to heal and the neck to be immobilized, which helps prevent further injury.

question: A 49-year-old Caucasian woman presents to your office for elevated blood pressure. She is a nurse and checks her blood pressure regularly while working in the wards. She presents with readings ranging between 163/101 and 156/94 mm Hg. After some research she conducted on her own, she has been exercising and following a low-fat, low-salt diet for the past 3 months. Her past medical history includes laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis 2 years previously. Her mother and father have hypertension and her father had myocardial infarction at the age of 68 years. She takes no medications and denies smoking. She drinks 3 glasses of wine a week. Her blood pressure in the office after more than 10 minutes of rest was 153/89 mm Hg in her left arm and 145/90 mm Hg in her right arm. A review of her medical record reveals that her blood pressure was 142/92 mm Hg at her visit 1 year ago. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
prompt:
A 49-year-old Caucasian woman presents to your office for elevated blood pressure. She is a nurse and checks her blood pressure regularly while working in the wards. She presents with readings ranging between 163/101 and 156/94 mm Hg. After some research she conducted on her own, she has been exercising and following a low-fat, low-salt diet for the past 3 months. Her past medical history includes laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis 2 years previously. Her mother and father have hypertension and her father had myocardial infarction at the age of 68 years. She takes no medications and denies smoking. She drinks 3 glasses of wine a week. Her blood pressure in the office after more than 10 minutes of rest was 153/89 mm Hg in her left arm and 145/90 mm Hg in her right arm. A review of her medical record reveals that her blood pressure was 142/92 mm Hg at her visit 1 year ago. Which of the following is the best next step in management?A)Liver function tests
B)Urine microalbumin
C)Hemoglobin A1C
D)Blood glucose
output0: The best next step in management for this patient would be to perform liver function tests (LFTs). This is because the patient has a history of cholecystectomy and is taking no medications, which may indicate that she has a higher risk of developing liver disease. Additionally, the patient's family history of hypertension and her own history of elevated blood pressure suggest that she may be at risk for cardiovascular disease, which is a common comorbidity with liver disease. LFTs would help determine if there is any liver damage or dysfunction.
output1: The best next step in management for this patient would be to perform urine microalbumin testing. This is because her blood pressure is elevated and she has a family history of hypertension and cardiovascular disease. Additionally, her recent exercise and dietary changes may have contributed to her hypertension. Urine microalbumin testing can help identify whether her hypertension is due to renal disease or other underlying conditions.
output2: The best next step in management for this patient would be to perform a Hemoglobin A1C test. This is because she has a history of hypertension in her family, and her recent blood pressure readings are elevated. Additionally, she has been following a low-fat, low-salt diet for the past 3 months, which may have caused her blood pressure to decrease, but it is still within the normal range. The Hemoglobin A1C test will give an indication of her average blood glucose control over the past 2-3 months, which will help determine if her dietary changes have had any impact on her blood sugar control.
output3: The best next step in management for this patient would be to perform a blood glucose test. The patient's history of hypertension and family history of hypertension and cardiovascular disease, along with her recent initiation of self-monitoring and dietary changes, suggest that she may be at risk for developing type 2 diabetes. Additionally, her elevated blood pressure and the fact that she has been exercising and following a low-fat, low-salt diet for the past 3 months suggest that she may be experiencing the metabolic syndrome. A blood glucose test would help to confirm or rule out the diagnosis of type 2 diabetes.

question: A 45-year-old woman diagnosed with follicular lymphoma and undergoing treatment with polychemotherapy (R-CHOP). Enter for pleuritic pain on the left side. The chest radiograph shows a moderate amount of pleural effusion and thoracocentesis shows a serohemorrhagic exudate with 12,000 leukocytes / uL with predominance of neutrophils and absence of mesothelial cells. Ziehl staining and mycobacterial culture were negative and adenosine deaminase in pleural fluid was slightly elevated. Of the following, what would be the most cost-effective diagnostic test?
options: D)Determination of lysozyme in pleural fluid.
prompt:
A 45-year-old woman diagnosed with follicular lymphoma and undergoing treatment with polychemotherapy (R-CHOP). Enter for pleuritic pain on the left side. The chest radiograph shows a moderate amount of pleural effusion and thoracocentesis shows a serohemorrhagic exudate with 12,000 leukocytes / uL with predominance of neutrophils and absence of mesothelial cells. Ziehl staining and mycobacterial culture were negative and adenosine deaminase in pleural fluid was slightly elevated. Of the following, what would be the most cost-effective diagnostic test?A)Pleural biopsy with needle
B)Positron emission tomography (PET).
C)Culture of mycobacteria in blood.
D)Determination of lysozyme in pleural fluid.
output0: Pleural biopsy with needle is the most cost-effective diagnostic test for this patient because it allows for a definitive diagnosis of the condition, and it is less invasive and less expensive than other diagnostic tests such as positron emission tomography (PET) or culture of mycobacteria in blood. Additionally, the presence of pleural effusion and the predominance of neutrophils in the pleural fluid are consistent with a diagnosis of tuberculosis, which can be confirmed by a pleural biopsy.
output1: Positron emission tomography (PET) is the most cost-effective diagnostic test for this patient. The presence of pleural effusion, predominance of neutrophils, and absence of mesothelial cells are all indicative of a non-infectious etiology, and the negative results of Ziehl staining and mycobacterial culture support this. Additionally, the elevated adenosine deaminase in pleural fluid suggests that there is an inflammatory process present. PET would allow for the evaluation of the extent of the disease and the response to treatment, which would be useful information for the patient's oncologist.
output2: The most cost-effective diagnostic test for a patient with pleuritic pain and suspected tuberculosis would be a culture of mycobacteria in the blood. This test is relatively inexpensive and can provide a definitive diagnosis of tuberculosis. Additionally, it can be performed in a local laboratory and does not require specialized equipment or expertise.
output3: The determination of lysozyme in pleural fluid is the most cost-effective diagnostic test for this patient. Lysozyme is an enzyme that is produced by cells of the immune system and is present in the pleural fluid in cases of tuberculosis. In this case, the absence of mesothelial cells in the pleural fluid and the presence of neutrophils and a serohemorrhagic exudate suggest that the patient may have tuberculosis. The Ziehl staining and mycobacterial culture were negative, so the determination of lysozyme in pleural fluid would be the most cost-effective diagnostic test to rule out tuberculosis.

question: A child presented to an ohopaedic clinic with a limp. The surgeon suspected him to have a fixed fledon deformity of the hip. Which test should the surgeon perform to confirm his finding?
prompt:
A child presented to an ohopaedic clinic with a limp. The surgeon suspected him to have a fixed fledon deformity of the hip. Which test should the surgeon perform to confirm his finding?A)Thomas test
B)Trendelenburgs test
C)Nelatons test
D)Telescoping test
output0: The Thomas test is the most commonly used test to confirm a fixed flexion deformity of the hip. The test involves flexing the hip joint and then extending it while the patient is standing on the leg with the suspected deformity. The test is positive if the patient is unable to extend the affected leg and maintain the standing position.
output1: The Trendelenburgs test is performed by placing the patient in a Trendelenburg position (on their back with their legs raised) and then checking for a positive result (the patient will have a limp or a difference in the height of their legs). This test is used to confirm the diagnosis of a fixed flefon deformity of the hip.
output2: The Nelatons test is used to assess the presence of a fixed flexion deformity of the hip. This test involves having the child stand on one leg while the examiner holds the opposite leg straight and attempts to flex the hip. If the child is unable to actively resist this movement, it may indicate a fixed flexion deformity.
output3: The Telescoping test is a specific test used to assess for fixed flexion deformity of the hip. It involves placing the patient in a position where the affected limb is hanging straight down and then bringing the limb into flexion. The test is positive if the patient is unable to actively extend the affected limb beyond 90 degrees of flexion.

question: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 6-hour history of severe eye pain and blurry vision. He wears soft contact lenses and has not removed them for 2 days. Ophthalmologic examination shows a deep corneal ulcer, severe conjunctival injection, and purulent discharge on the right. Treatment with topical ciprofloxacin is initiated. A culture of the ocular discharge is most likely to show which of the following?
prompt:
A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 6-hour history of severe eye pain and blurry vision. He wears soft contact lenses and has not removed them for 2 days. Ophthalmologic examination shows a deep corneal ulcer, severe conjunctival injection, and purulent discharge on the right. Treatment with topical ciprofloxacin is initiated. A culture of the ocular discharge is most likely to show which of the following?A)Gram-negative, non-maltose fermenting diplococci
B)Gram-negative, lactose-fermenting bacilli
C)Gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacilli
D)Gram-positive, optochin-sensitive diplococci
"
output0: The most likely organism causing a deep corneal ulcer with severe conjunctival injection and purulent discharge is a Gram-negative, non-maltose fermenting diplococcus, such as Staphylococcus aureus. The presence of purulent discharge and the severity of the symptoms suggest that the infection is more likely to be caused by a Gram-negative bacterium, rather than a Gram-positive bacterium.
output1: The most likely organism causing the corneal ulcer and purulent discharge in this case is a Gram-negative, lactose-fermenting bacillus, such as Staphylococcus aureus. The presence of purulent discharge and the patient's history of contact lens use suggest that the infection is likely to be caused by a bacterial organism. The Gram stain and culture of the ocular discharge will help to identify the specific pathogen and guide antibiotic therapy.
output2: The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is a bacterial infection, specifically a Staphylococcus aureus infection. This bacterium is gram-negative and oxidase-positive, which is consistent with the culture results.
output3: The most likely organism causing a deep corneal ulcer with severe conjunctival injection and purulent discharge is Staphylococcus aureus. This bacterium is gram-positive and optochin-sensitive, which is consistent with the symptoms and physical examination findings described.

question: A cross-over experimental study on the effect of two different treatments:
correct_answer: It randomly establishes the order of application of the treatments.
options: A)Randomly establish pairs of subjects to be treated.
B)Choose randomly the experimental group of the population.
C)It randomly establishes the order of application of the treatments.
D)It does not use any type of randomization.
prompt:
A cross-over experimental study on the effect of two different treatments:A)Randomly establish pairs of subjects to be treated.
B)Choose randomly the experimental group of the population.
C)It randomly establishes the order of application of the treatments.
D)It does not use any type of randomization.
output0: The correct answer is A)Randomly establish pairs of subjects to be treated because it is a more reliable method for establishing the effectiveness of a treatment. Randomly pairing subjects helps to minimize bias and ensure that the results are due to the intervention being tested and not to other factors.
output1: The correct answer is B)Choose randomly the experimental group of the population. This is because the randomization of the experimental group is essential to ensure that there are no systematic differences between the groups, which could influence the results of the study.
output2: The correct answer is C)It randomly establishes the order of application of the treatments. This is because a cross-over experimental study involves comparing the two treatments with each participant receiving both treatments, and the order in which they receive the treatments is randomly assigned.
output3: The Turtle Technique is not a randomized controlled trial. It is a non-randomized, quasi-experimental design, which means that the subjects are not randomly assigned to the treatment or control groups.

question: A 17-year-old female accidentally eats a granola bar manufactured on equipment that processes peanuts. She develops type I hypersensitivity-mediated histamine release, resulting in pruritic wheals on the skin. Which of the following layers of this patient's skin would demonstrate histologic changes on biopsy of her lesions?
prompt:
A 17-year-old female accidentally eats a granola bar manufactured on equipment that processes peanuts. She develops type I hypersensitivity-mediated histamine release, resulting in pruritic wheals on the skin. Which of the following layers of this patient's skin would demonstrate histologic changes on biopsy of her lesions?A)Stratum corneum
B)Stratum granulosum
C)Stratum basale
D)Dermis
output0: The histologic changes in type I hypersensitivity reactions occur primarily in the stratum corneum, which is the outermost layer of the skin. The stratum corneum is composed of dead, flattened cells that are held together by lipid bilayers. When the patient's immune system is exposed to an allergen, it releases histamine, which causes the lipid bilayers to break down and allow water to enter the stratum corneum. This leads to the formation of pruritic wheals on the skin.
output1: The histologic changes that occur in the skin during type I hypersensitivity-mediated histamine release are primarily seen in the stratum granulosum layer of the skin. This layer is composed of keratinocytes that are in the process of undergoing differentiation and maturation. When histamine is released, it causes the keratinocytes to undergo apoptosis, or programmed cell death, which results in the formation of the characteristic histologic changes seen in allergic contact dermatitis.
output2: The histologic changes in type I hypersensitivity reactions are typically found in the stratum basale, the deepest layer of the epidermis. This layer is where the immune cells responsible for the allergic response reside. Biopsy of the patient's lesions would likely show histologic changes in the stratum basale, such as infiltration of immune cells and increased expression of inflammatory mediators.
output3: The histologic changes in type I hypersensitivity-mediated histamine release, such as pruritic wheals, occur in the dermis. Therefore, the dermis would demonstrate histologic changes on biopsy of the patient's lesions.

question: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a rash on his hands and feet for the past two weeks. It is intensely pruritic, especially at night. He has not had fever, headache, or diarrhea. His mother has a history of eczema. The child was due for an appointment later in the week to follow up on any potentially missing vaccinations. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F). Examination shows a maculopapular rash with linear patterns affecting the interdigital spaces of the fingers and toes. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most effective intervention for this patient's skin lesion?
prompt:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a rash on his hands and feet for the past two weeks. It is intensely pruritic, especially at night. He has not had fever, headache, or diarrhea. His mother has a history of eczema. The child was due for an appointment later in the week to follow up on any potentially missing vaccinations. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F). Examination shows a maculopapular rash with linear patterns affecting the interdigital spaces of the fingers and toes. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most effective intervention for this patient's skin lesion?A)Oral acyclovir
B)Supportive care
C)Topical permethrin
D)Topical clotrimazole
output0: Oral acyclovir is the most effective intervention for this patient's skin lesion because it is a treatment for herpes simplex virus (HSV), which is the most common cause of maculopapular rashes with linear patterns affecting the interdigital spaces of the fingers and toes. The patient's symptoms of pruritus and the presence of a rash on the hands and feet suggest a viral etiology.
output1: The most effective intervention for this patient's skin lesion is supportive care, as the rash is likely due to a viral infection such as herpes simplex virus (HSV). The use of antiviral medications such as acyclovir is not recommended for herpes simplex virus infections in children, as they can have adverse effects on the developing immune system. Topical permethrin and clotrimazole are both effective for treating fungal infections, but they are not appropriate for this patient's condition.
output2: The most effective intervention for the patient's skin lesion is topical permethrin. This is because the patient's symptoms and physical examination are consistent with a diagnosis of eczema, a common skin condition that is often treated with topical corticosteroids. Permethrin is a topical corticosteroid that is commonly used to treat eczema and other skin conditions. It is effective in reducing inflammation and relieving itching, which are the primary symptoms of the patient's condition.
output3: Topical clotrimazole is the most effective intervention for this patient's skin lesion because it is an antifungal medication that is commonly used to treat tinea pedis (athlete's foot), which is a common cause of maculopapular rashes in children. The patient's symptoms of itching and the linear patterns of the rash suggest that tinea pedis may be the cause. Additionally, the patient's history of eczema may increase the likelihood of a fungal infection.

question: One of the first-line treatments for generalized anxiety disorder includes the use of a:
options: A)Negative modulator of the GABA-A receptor.
C)Negative modulator of the GABA-B receptor.
prompt:
One of the first-line treatments for generalized anxiety disorder includes the use of a:A)Negative modulator of the GABA-A receptor.
B)Partial serotonergic antagonist 1A.
C)Negative modulator of the GABA-B receptor.
D)Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.
output0: A negative modulator of the GABA-A receptor is a first-line treatment for generalized anxiety disorder because it can help reduce excessive anxiety and fear responses. This type of treatment works by decreasing the activity of the GABA-A receptor, which can lead to a decrease in anxiety symptoms.
output1: Partial serotonergic antagonists, such as paroxetine, are commonly used to treat generalized anxiety disorder. These medications work by blocking the action of serotonin in the brain, which can help to reduce anxiety symptoms.
output2: One of the first-line treatments for generalized anxiety disorder is a negative modulator of the GABA-B receptor, such as a benzodiazepine. This type of medication can help reduce anxiety symptoms by increasing the activity of the neurotransmitter GABA, which has a calming effect on the brain.
output3: The Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) are the most commonly used medications to treat generalized anxiety disorder. These medications work by increasing the levels of serotonin in the brain, which helps to reduce symptoms of anxiety.

question: What does it mean that "there is cooperativity" when oxygen binds to deoxyhemoglobin ?:
correct_answer: That the entrance of the first oxygen causes conformational changes in the tetramer of hemoglobin so that the entrance of the second is facilitated, this one of the third and so on.
options: A)That the entrance of the first oxygen causes conformational changes in the tetramer of hemoglobin and then the following oxygens enter with greater difficulty.
B)That the entrance of the first oxygen causes conformational changes in the tetramer of hemoglobin so that the entrance of the second is facilitated, this one of the third and so on.
C)That CO2 facilitates the entry of oxygen.
D)That oxygen displaces CO2 from hemoglobin.
prompt:
What does it mean that "there is cooperativity" when oxygen binds to deoxyhemoglobin ?:A)That the entrance of the first oxygen causes conformational changes in the tetramer of hemoglobin and then the following oxygens enter with greater difficulty.
B)That the entrance of the first oxygen causes conformational changes in the tetramer of hemoglobin so that the entrance of the second is facilitated, this one of the third and so on.
C)That CO2 facilitates the entry of oxygen.
D)That oxygen displaces CO2 from hemoglobin.
output0: When oxygen binds to deoxyhemoglobin, it causes conformational changes in the tetramer of hemoglobin, which makes it more difficult for subsequent oxygens to bind. This process is known as cooperativity.
output1: When oxygen binds to deoxyhemoglobin, it causes conformational changes in the tetramer of hemoglobin that facilitate the entry of subsequent oxygen molecules. This cooperativity is due to the changes in the tertiary structure of the protein that occur when the first oxygen binds, which in turn affect the binding of the next oxygen molecules.
output2: When CO2 binds to hemoglobin, it causes conformational changes that facilitate the entry of oxygen. This is known as the Bohr effect.
output3: When oxygen binds to deoxyhemoglobin, it displaces carbon dioxide (CO2) from the hemoglobin molecule. This allows for the release of CO2 from the body and the entry of oxygen into the tissues.
